moves.1. e4: e4 so I come out with my standard reply d6
moves.1... d6 2. d4 Nf6 3. Nc3 g6: By now Im am firmly set up in the Pirc defense
moves.4. f4: The deadly Austrian Attack!  White goes for complete control in the center and looks to squash Black before Black can come up with adequate counter-play.
moves.5. Nf3: White continues their buildup in the center
moves.5... Qb6: Qb6!?  A curious move without a great deal of theory available-I like that against the Austrian Attack.  So I elect to take us into the less explored territory Qb6.
moves.7. O-O e5: But I dont!   Its time to counter-attack in the center! Now that the King has castled to g1, I am hoping to exploit the fact that my Queen on b6 sits on a potentially threatening diagonal.....
moves.8. Kh1: White blinks.  He moves his King to h1 before starting offensive operations (The Queen on b6 did her job)and has now lost some tempo....good!
moves.8... exd4 9. Nxd4 Nxe4: Whites Huge center is falling and the Austrian Attack is losing steam. And now blacks fianchetto's bishop and Queen are laying claim to important diagonals
moves.10. Be3: White is now reacting and has comepltely lost tempo. Unfourtunaltly Blacks lack of castling yet threatens to hand tempo right back to White.....
moves.11. bxc3 c5: Save to do because black does not have to worry about whates queen going to A4 this game. White has taken on a structural weakness in the form of the doubled up pawns on the C-file.  The pawn on c3 is especially weak
moves.12. Nb5 O-O: I figured I would have to give up the backward d pawn.  But I was ok with that, we would be even in material, but I like my pawn structure and postion better. I had faced the dreaded Austrian Attack formation and chip away at it till it was no more. That all you can ask from a opening really, the rest is up to the player.  The Pirc gave me pariaty going into the middlegame, which means the Pirc defense did its job.  I like Qb6 I think Pirc players who run into the Austrian Attack should give it a look.
